name: Bangunan Sultan Abdul Samad
architects: AC Norman, RAJ Bidwell, CE Spooner, AB Hubback
info: This was the Government Offices of the British Colonial administration. The two-storey building is 480ft long with a wide arched colonnade. The imposing clock tower rises to over 140ft. It now holds the offices of the National Heritage Department.

name: Old Post Office
info: Designed by AB Hubback at a cost of $100,000 (Straits Dollars), its style is similar to the Sultan Abdul Samad building. It remained the General Post Office until 1984 and is now used by the Ministry of Tourism and Culture.

name: Wisma Straits Trading, Loke Yew Building & Chow Kit & Co. Building
architects: B.M. Iversen (Loke Yew Bldg), AK Moosden (Chow Kit Bldg)
info: This group includes the Loke Yew Building, an iconic six-storey Art Deco structure, and the Chow Kit & Co. Building, built in a Neo-Renaissance style. The latter was adapted for new use as the Industrial Court of Malaysia.

name: Masjid Jamek
info: Located on the site of a Malay cemetery at the confluence of the Klang and Gombak rivers. The design is said to be inspired by North Indian Moghul mosques, with distinctive red and white masonry bands. It was the main mosque in KL until Masjid Negara opened in 1965.

name: Medan Pasar (Old Market Square)
info: This was the original township center with Kapitan Yap Ah Loy's market and gambling sheds. The ornate three-storey Neo-classical shophouses were built in 1907. The Art Deco Clock Tower in the center was erected in 1937 to commemorate the coronation of King George VI.

name: Sze Ya Temple
info: The oldest traditional Chinese temple in the city. The board at the entrance attributes Kapitan Yap Ah Loy as the founder in 1864. It is dedicated to the patron deities of Sin Sze Ya and Si Sze Ya, who are said to have guided Yap Ah Loy to victory during the Selangor Civil War.

name: The Triangle (Bangkok Bank Triangle)
info: This triangle is formed by the conjunction of Jalan Tun HS Lee and Jalan Petaling. It features several distinctive shophouses, such as the unique Old Federal Stores Building, which was occupied by the founders of the Cycle and Carriage Company in 1905.

name: Kedai Ubat Kwong Ban Heng
info: Located at No 62, Jalan Tun Perak. Established over 30 years ago, it retains many traditional fixtures and fittings, such as glass cabinets and shelving. You can find different types of traditional herbs and medicines here.

name: Oriental Building
info: One of KL's distinctive heritage buildings, located at the intersection of Jalan Tun Perak and Jalan Melaka. At five storeys, it was the tallest in Kuala Lumpur at that time. It originally housed Radio Malaya and is now leased by CIMB Bank.

name: Flower Garland Stalls
info: Located across the street from the Oriental Building, near the Teochew Association. These stalls are where you can learn how to make a traditional flower garland or buy fresh flowers.

name: Masjid India
info: Began as a timber building with an attap roof in 1893. The new mosque, which can accommodate 3,500 people, was opened in 1966. It is built in the Southern Indian style, and prayer service continues to be conducted in both Arabic and Tamil.

name: P.H. Hendry Royal Jewellers
info: The oldest existing jewellers in Malaysia. P.H. Hendry Jewellers was established in 1902. The three coats of arms on their business card attest that they were appointed royal jewellers to the Sultans of Selangor, Kelantan, and Negeri Sembilan in the 1920s.

name: Panggong Bandaraya (Old City Hall)
info: Designed by AB Hubback, this building originally housed the Kuala Lumpur Town Hall and Municipal Offices. Architecturally, it carries the Moghul style of the Bangunan Sultan Abdul Samad. The Auditorium is now the venue for the popular musical 'MUD: Our story of Kuala Lumpur'.

name: Dataran Merdeka
info: Originally known as the Padang, it was the focal point of colonial Kuala Lumpur. At the stroke of midnight on 31 August 1957, the Union Jack was lowered here, and Malaya became an independent nation. On the south side is a 100m tall flagpole.

name: National Textile Museum
info: Originally built as the FMS Railway Offices, it was taken over by the PWD in 1917 and now houses the Textile Museum. The fa√ßade is in the Moghul style with distinctive red and white banding, achieved by alternating fair-faced bricks with plastered bricks.

name: OCBC Building
info: This Art Deco building was the headquarters of the Overseas Chinese Banking Corporation (OCBC). The design was innovative for its time as it provided basement storage for bicycles. A muted mosaic panel runs up the pylon, ending with the original bank logo of a Chinese junk.

name: Central Market (Pasar Seni)
info: This Art Deco building served as KL's wholesale wet market until the mid-1980s. It was restored and adapted into an art and culture market in 1986. When built, it was the largest room in the city at 120m long x 60m wide.

name: Jalan Yap Ah Loy
info: A short road with high historical significance, it led to Kapitan Yap Ah Loy's house on Lebuh Pasar Besar.

name: Lebuh Ampang
info: This street still has many Indian restaurants, spice stores, and money-lenders. It was the street of the Chettiar, a south Indian caste of money-lenders. An example is No 85, decorated with glazed ceramic tiles of peacock designs.

name: Jalan Melaka
info: Walking up this street, you pass major modern buildings like Bank Muamalat, which has a banking hall built following the design of a traditional Malay House.

name: Selangor Mansion & Malayan Mansion
info: An early example of mass public housing in the newly independent Malaya. These are eight-storey buildings with retail on the ground floor and 160 residential flats on the subsequent floors.

name: Wisma Yakin
info: An 11-storey building developed by Malay entrepreneurs supported by PKNS. It was the tallest building in the area when first built and remains the 'must-go' place to buy Baju Melayu or songkok.

name: Jalan Melayu
info: Also known as Malay Street, this was named for the Malay settlers in the area. A prominent owner from the 1870s was Haji Mohamed Eusop bin Abubakar, a sea captain from Terengganu.

name: Batu Road (Jalan TAR)
info: Now Jalan Tuanku Abdul Rahman (Jalan TAR). It was so named because it began as a track leading to the limestone caves and tin mines at Batu. By the 1930s, this road became a busy commercial hub.

name: Old Survey Office
info: Designed by AB Hubback, this building features a dramatic 400 ft (121.6m) long arcade along Jalan Tun Perak. Sadly, this is now eclipsed by the LRT line which runs above the street. It was later turned into the Sessions and Magistrates Courts but is no longer in use.

name: Old High Court
info: Also designed by AB Hubback, it replaced the Supreme Courts which had been located on Court Hill. The public entrance faces the river and leads to a grand inner courtyard. It now stands vacant but expectations are that it will be restored for new use by Kraftangan Malaysia.
